case_name: Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 416 of 1958 and 19 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 416 of 1958 and 19 of 1959. Appeals by special leave from the Award dated January 13, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 218 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the Award dated January 13, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference I. T. No. 218 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the Award dated January 13, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 218 of 1957. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, N. A. Pal- khivala, G. B. Pai and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant  In C.A. No. 416 of 58  and respondent No. 1  In C.A. No. 19 of 1959 .

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on January 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-These two cross-appeals Go arise from an industrial dispute between the Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd.  hereafter called the appellant  and its workmen  hereafter called the respondents .

facts.text: Industrial dispute between the Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd. (appellant) and its workmen (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: These two cross-appeals Go arise from an industrial dispute between the Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd.  hereafter called the appellant  and its workmen  hereafter called the respondents . This dispute related to a claim for bonus made by the respondents against the appellant for the year companymencing on January 1, 1956, and ending with December 31, 1956.

facts.text: Dispute related to claim for bonus for the year commencing on January 1, 1956, and ending with December 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute related to a claim for bonus made by the respondents against the appellant for the year companymencing on January 1, 1956, and ending with December 31, 1956. The respondents claimed that for the relevant year they were entitled to receive by way of bonus their nine months total earnings inclusive of all allowances and overtime and extra-time earnings.

facts.text: Respondents claimed entitlement to nine months total earnings inclusive of all allowances and overtime as bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claimed that for the relevant year they were entitled to receive by way of bonus their nine months total earnings inclusive of all allowances and overtime and extra-time earnings. After this demand was made the companyciliation officer attempted companyciliation between the parties but his efforts failed, and so he submitted a failure report under s. 12 4  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 .

facts.text: Conciliation officer attempted conciliation, efforts failed, submitted failure report under s. 12(4) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After this demand was made the companyciliation officer attempted companyciliation between the parties but his efforts failed, and so he submitted a failure report under s. 12 4  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  XIV of 1947 . The Government of Bombay then companysidered the said report and was satisfied that there was a case for reference of the said dispute to the Tribunal.

facts.text: Government of Bombay referred the dispute to the Tribunal under s. 12(5) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bombay then companysidered the said report and was satisfied that there was a case for reference of the said dispute to the Tribunal. That is how the present reference came to be made under s. 12 5  of the Act,. The respondents who have made the present claim include 648 employees amongst them 524 are operatives and 124 belong to the clerical cadre.

facts.text: Respondents include 648 employees: 524 operatives and 124 clerical cadre.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents who have made the present claim include 648 employees amongst them 524 are operatives and 124 belong to the clerical cadre. Before the Tribunal the respondents case was that during the companyciliation proceedings the appellant had admitted its capacity to pay and to meet the entire claim of bonus made by them

facts.text: Appellant had voluntarily paid three months basic wages to the respondents by way of bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the appellant had already voluntarily paid three months basic wages to the respondents by way of bonus, but since the respondents were making a much larger claim the appellant thought it necessary to raise this general issue of law and to companytend that the respondents were number entitled to any bonus at all.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded five months basic earnings excluding dearness and other allowances and overtime as bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly it has made an award to that effect and has issued appropriate directions in that behalf. This award is challenged by the appellant in its Civil Appeal No. 416 of 1958, and it is urged by the learned Attorney-General on its behalf that the tribunal should have held that the appellant was paying a living wage to the respondents

facts.text: Tribunal held that wages are fair but there is still in a large number of cases a gap between the actual wage and the living wage.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, having broadly companysidered the companytentions raised by the appellant it held that the wages are fair but there is still in a large number of cases a gap between the actual wage and the living wage. On this finding the Tribunal proceeded to examine the other companytentions raised by the parties

facts.text: Respondents alleged that appellant admitted capacity to pay entire bonus claim during conciliation.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal the respondents case was that during the companyciliation proceedings the appellant had admitted its capacity to pay and to meet the entire claim of bonus made by them and so it was urged that it was unnecessary to screen the respondents claim through the Full Bench formula.

facts.text: Appellant denied admitting capacity to pay entire bonus during conciliation.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was denied by the appellant. It denied the respondents allegation that during companyciliation proceedings it had admitted its capacity to pay the entire amount of bonus claimed by the respondents. It then specifically averred that in law the respondents were number entitled to any bonus

facts.text: Appellant claimed paying living wage, so no entitlement to bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It then specifically averred that in law the respondents were number entitled to any bonus because the appellant was paying them a living wage and so one of the essential companyditions for the payment of bonus, namely, the need to fill the gap between the actual wage and the living wage was absent in the present case.

facts.text: Appellant set out calculations of average wages paid to different categories.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then set out its calculations in regard to the average wages paid to the different categories of respondents and supported its plea that they were number entitled to any bonus at all.

facts.text: Average wage for 524 operatives: Rs. 273.65 including basic, DA, amenities.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the class of operatives which companyprises 524 workmen the average wage packet companysisting of the basic salary, the dearness allowance and the value of the amenities supplied by the appellant to them equals Rs. 273.65 nP.

facts.text: Average wages for 124 clerks: Rs. 370.11.

anchor.surface_text: The average wages in regard to the 124 clerks reach the figure of Rs. 370.11 nP., and the average wages for the total employees taken together reach the figure of Rs. 301.16 nP.

facts.text: Average wages for total 648 employees: Rs. 301.16.

anchor.surface_text: and the average wages for the total employees taken together reach the figure of Rs. 301.16 nP. According to the appellant whichever figure is taken it is much above Rs. 192.50 nP., and that must lead to the inference that the living wage standard has been reached by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant paid three months basic wages as bonus voluntarily for relevant year, and agreement reached for bonus until 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the appellant has paid three months basic wages as bonus to the respondents voluntarily for the relevant year, and we were told that an agreement has been reached between the parties in respect of bonus for subsequent years until 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellant's request to remand for further evidence.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us the learned Attorney-General suggested that we should remand the case to enable his client to lead further and more satisfactory evidence. We have rejected this request.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that appellant is not paying living wage to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the claim made by the appellant that it is paying a living wage to its employees cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Both appeals dismissed, award of five months bonus upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the result both the appeals fail and are dismissed.

holdings.text: The appellant is not paying a living wage to its employees, and the claim that there is no gap between actual wages and living wage barring bonus entitlement cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the claim made by the appellant that it is paying a living wage to its employees cannot be sustained. It still remains to consider some of the decisions to which our attention was invited.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines wage averages (Rs.273-370), rejects 1940 Textile Committee figure as minimum not living wage, defines living wage as idealistic/expanding including education/amusement; wages approximate fair wage only.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's award of five months basic earnings as bonus is reasonable and strikes a fair balance; no higher quantum warranted.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the tribunal has considered all the relevant factors and has come to the conclusion that five months bonus would meet the ends of justice. We do not see any reason to interfere with this award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Available surplus large, but award balances industry/shareholders/workmen claims; no rigid formula or ceiling; discretion of tribunal upheld.

holdings.text: No interference with Tribunal's award under Article 136 as it is not wholly unreasonable and considers relevant factors.

anchor.surface_text: It is only where the award passed by the tribunal appears to this Court to be wholly unreasonable and to be the result of the failure of the tribunal to take into account the necessary relevant facts that the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 can be successfully invoked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited jurisdiction under Art.136; Tribunal considered all factors including wage scales, surplus; award meets ends of justice.

holdings.text: Request for remand to lead further evidence on living wage rejected.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us the learned Attorney-General suggested that we should remand the case to enable his client to lead further and more satisfactory evidence. We have rejected this request. The appellant knew fully well the implications of the plea raised by it...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant aware of issue importance, failed to produce evidence earlier despite opportunities; no indulgence at appellate stage.

holdings.text: No rigid ceiling or formula should be imposed on quantum of bonus; depends on facts balancing industry, shareholders, workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it would be inadvisable and inexpedient to put such a ceiling in the matter of awarding bonus. It is not well established that in awarding bonus industrial adjudication has to take into account the legitimate claims of the industry, its shareholders...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distribution of surplus case-specific; high profits/low wages justify higher bonus; avoids extravagance or regional disparity.

holdings.text: Both appeals fail and are dismissed; Tribunal's award upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the result both the appeals fail and are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Living wage claim rejected; bonus quantum reasonable; no jurisdictional basis for interference.

holdings.text: Decision does not preclude bonus claims on profit-sharing basis even if living wage standard reached (obiter).

anchor.surface_text: ...our decision in the present appeal should not be taken to mean that as soon as a living wage standard is reached no claim for bonus can be made by the workmen that is a question which may have to be considered on its merits if and when it arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical; no employer yet proved living wage; issue arises only then; clarifies non-preclusive effect.

holdings.text: 1940 Textile Labour Committee conclusions do not represent living wage but need-based minimum wage.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it would be unreasonable and unsafe to treat the conclusions of this Committee as to the monetary value of the living wage in 1940 as sound and to make it the basis of our calculations today.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee data insufficient, negative inquiry, minimum-level calculations; social justice evolved; multiplication method defective.

precedents.citation: Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur 1

anchor.surface_text: the point  Vide Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur  1  The Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen  2 . We will revert to this point later. Meanwhile let us proceed to examine the merits of the contention that the appellant is paying the respondents a living wage.

precedents.case_name: Muir Mills Co Ltd v Suti Mills Mazdoor Union Kanpur
precedents.cited_proposition: Result of relevant decisions supporting that bonus fills gap between actual wage and living wage as labour contributes to profits.

precedents.citation: The Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: Vide Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur  1  The Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen  2 . We will revert to this point later. Meanwhile let us proceed to examine the merits of the contention that the appellant is paying the respondents a living wage. It is well known that the problem of wage structure with which industrial adjudication is concerned in a modern democratic State involves on the ultimate analysis to some extent ethical and social considerations.

precedents.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Result of relevant decisions supporting that bonus fills gap between actual wage and living wage as labour contributes to profits.

precedents.citation: Express Newspapers Private Ltd. v. The Union of India 3

anchor.surface_text: This Court has recognised this idealistic position of the concept of living wage in the case of Express Newspapers Private Ltd. v. The Union of India  3 . It would thus be obvious that the concept of a living wage is not a static concept it is expanding and the number of its constituents and their respective contents are bound to expand and widen with the development and growth of national economy.

precedents.case_name: Express Newspapers Pvt Ltd v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Recognised idealistic position of the concept of living wage.

anchor.surface_text: Australia which has been endorsed by the Fair Wages Committees Report and broadly approved by this Court in the Express Newspapers case  1 . The question which we must not consider is whether the appellant has succeeded in showing that its wage structure has reached the standard of the living wage which has been specified as one of the ultimate objectives by Art. 43 and which is the ideal that the working population of the country hopefully looks forward to achieve.

precedents.case_name: Express Newspapers Pvt Ltd v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Broadly approved tests for living wage laid down by Royal Commission endorsed by Fair Wages Committee.

precedents.citation: Standard Vacuum Oil Company. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: It still remains to consider some of the decisions to which our attention was invited. In Standard Vacuum Oil Company. Their Workmen 1  the tribunal had to consider the claim for bonus made by the employees, and in determining the quantm of bonus it addressed itself to the question as to the extent of the gap between the actual wage and the living wage which should be filled by the award of bonus.

precedents.case_name: Standard Vacuum Oil Company v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Used Rs 50-55 from Textile Committee report as money value of living wage in 1940 for gap calculation.

precedents.citation: Burmah-Shell, etc., Oil Companies in Madras v. Their Employees 1

anchor.surface_text: The same comment falls to be made about the calculations made by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Burmah-Shell, etc., Oil Companies in Madras v. Their Employees  1 . In that case the Appellate Tribunal thought that if 50 be added to the minimum wage of the employees that may assist them to attain the goal of the living wage, and this conclusion was based on the Textile Committees report.

precedents.case_name: Burmah-Shell Oil Companies in Madras v Their Employees
precedents.cited_proposition: Adding Rs 50 to minimum wage to attain living wage, based on Textile Committee.

precedents.citation: Workers of S. V. O. C. Ltd. Standard Vacuum Employees Union v. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the calculations made by the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in Workers of S. V. O. C. Ltd.  Standard Vacuum Employees Union  v. Standard Vacuum Oil Co. Ltd.  2 , suffers from the same infirmity. Therefore, the three industrial decisions on which the appellant relied cannot assist it in establishing its contention that a living wage is paid to the respondents.

precedents.case_name: Workers of SVOC Ltd Standard Vacuum Employees Union v Standard Vacuum Oil Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Calculations for living wage based on Textile Committee report.

precedents.citation: Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India, Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen 3

anchor.surface_text: In Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India, Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen  3  the Labour Appellate Tribunal had occasion to consider the content of the living wage. In that connection it referred to the Report of the Fair Wages Committee, and observed that the level of national income in India is so low that the country is unable to afford to prescribe by law a minimum wage which would correspond to the concept of a living wage.

precedents.case_name: Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co of India Ltd Bombay v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Content of living wage; low national income prevents affording living wage; correct approach.

precedents.citation: Standard Vacuum Oil Company v. Their Employees 1

anchor.surface_text: In Standard Vacuum Oil Company v. Their Employees  1  the Labour Appellate Tribunal was called upon to consider the plea that the companies were paying a living wage to their employees. In dealing with the said contention the Appellate Tribunal observed that the measurement of the living wage standard in terms of money has not been prescribed by law of the country, not, as far as we are aware, has been determined anywhere in any scientific basis.

precedents.case_name: Standard Vacuum Oil Company v Their Employees
precedents.cited_proposition: Rejected plea of paying living wage; no need for exact monetary figure for bonus purposes; approximate idea sufficient.

precedents.citation: Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: As has been observed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co. of India Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen  1  care must be taken to see that the bonus which is given is not so excessive as to create fresh problems in the vicinity that upset emoluments all-round or that it creates industrial discontent or the possible emergence of a privileged class.

precedents.case_name: Burmah-Shell Oil Storage and Distributing Co of India Ltd Bombay v Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: In awarding bonus, care must be taken not to make it excessive to avoid creating problems, industrial discontent or privileged class.

anchor.surface_text: In the result both the appeals fail and are dismissed.
